race.name: Gravel Suisse
race.tagline: Wild Alpine gravel from the World Cycling Center in Aigle to the heights of Villars.

climate.description: Generally mild to cool mountain conditions.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Swiss Alps. Significant elevation with Alpine scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional Swiss event. Alpine terrain with moderate access, high costs, and regional field.

biased_opinion.summary: Gravel Suisse is a regional event in Aigle, Switzerland—Alpine terrain with significant elevation. The Swiss Alps scenery is stunning, but the high costs and regional field keep it firmly in Tier 3. Switzerland travel is very expensive.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A scenic Swiss Alpine gravel race. Worth it for European cyclists with budgets. Not practical for most international riders due to cost.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're in Europe and have a good budget—yes, the Alps are worth it. If you're international or budget-conscious—there are better options.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better value: French/Italian Alps races. For similar Alpine terrain: Austrian gravel races.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Aigle has moderate lodging options. Switzerland is expensive.
logistics.food: Aigle has full dining options. Stock nutrition. Switzerland is expensive.

non_negotiables.why: Swiss Alpine terrain requires sustained effort.

logistics.explanation: The race starts at UCI headquarters in Aigle with 550+ riders annually, now awarded 2029 UCI Gravel World Championships. Team staff member Meth recalls Sophie Wright "rolled around the corner at the top of a mountain saying 'I've bloody won.'" Entry fees and packet pickup details remain unpublished.

length.explanation: Andreas Seewald won the 2025 men's race in 3:37:47 as "the five climbs shattered the field." The 100km Summit route with 3,300m+ climbing creates decisive separations - Seewald finished over 5 minutes ahead of second place, while Sophie Wright won by over 7 minutes in the women's race. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: The Summit route features forest roads and alpine paths through the Vaud Alps. Technical challenge comes from sustained gradients rather than handling skills - the race is consistently described as "climb heavy" where climbing ability determines outcomes rather than bike handling through technical terrain. Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: The Summit route delivers 3,300m+ of climbing over 100km from Aigle to Col de la Croix. The brutal second half includes 2,300m of the total elevation with a "very steep 20% section" on Route des Chaux. Racing consistently gets "decided on the final climb" as gradients separate contenders. More climbing than SBT GRVL at the same score.

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 78°F and lows of 60°F, with a 58% chance of rain on any given day. Late June to mid-July alpine weather in the Vaud Alps can shift from mild summer conditions to challenging mountain weather. The 2024 race dealt with "muddy, wet and gritty" conditions that transformed gravel sections, affecting race strategy and course difficulty throughout the climbing sections. Similar climate challenges to SBT GRVL.

altitude.explanation: Starting from Aigle at 380m, the Gran Fondo route climbs to 1,819m at its highest point 11km before the finish. The Summit route reaches Col de la Croix through sustained alpine climbing. Substantial altitude gain affects pacing without hitting oxygen-limiting elevations for sea-level riders. Similar altitude considerations to Grinduro. As Setting puts it: "Wild, demanding and infinitely alpine. From the World Cycling Center in Aigle to the heights of Villars, the Majestics Gravel crosses forests, ridges and high altitude paths, between silence and inten..."

adventure.explanation: The course travels "from the World Cycling Center in Aigle to the heights of Villars" through terrain described as "wild, demanding and infinitely alpine." After the first section, riders enter "mostly offroad" terrain crossing "forests, ridges and high altitude paths, between silence and intensity."

prestige.explanation: Sophie Wright's euphoric reaction - "I dream of days like this...today, it became reality. UCI World Series win. Feeling good as hell!!!" - shows elite riders value the victory. However, she admits "I didn't expect to win a UCI race in my first year as a pro gravel racer."

race_quality.explanation: The race earned 2029 UCI Gravel World Championships hosting rights and operates at UCI headquarters. However, Wright's surprise at winning "in my first year as a pro gravel racer" with a 7+ minute margin suggests the competitive field remains developing for a UCI World Series event.

experience.explanation: Sophie Wright captured the experience: "when I caught the girl who was leading in the final 20km, I had so much motivation and adrenaline to absolutely empty myself all the way to the finish line." The route delivers "mostly offroad" alpine terrain through spectacular Vaud Alps landscapes.

community.explanation: The race debuted in 2024 at "the doorsteps of the UCI headquarters in Aigle" with special significance in gravel racing. Set in Villars-sur-Ollon at 1,300m elevation, described as "a charming and picturesque village that embodies the beauty and charm of Switzerland" with authentic Swiss ambiance.

field_depth.explanation: Sophie Wright won by over 7 minutes in 2025 after catching the leader "in the final 20km." Andreas Seewald similarly dominated with a 5+ minute men's victory. Large winning margins in elite categories suggest limited depth despite UCI World Series status and automatic Worlds qualification. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100.

value.explanation: Awarded 2029 UCI Gravel World Championships hosting rights with automatic qualification for top 25% finishers, delivering serious UCI Series credentials. The race location offers "charming accommodations and exquisite culinary options" in Villars, but entry fees remain unpublished with typical Swiss premium pricing expected.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs €100-150. Racing in Switzerland with accommodations in Villars-sur-Ollon, a resort village at 1,300m elevation in the Vaud Alps. Swiss pricing impacts every expense from lodging to meals in this "charming and picturesque village." Geneva Airport 80km away adds international travel costs to premium Swiss rates. More expensive than Atlas Mountain Race.

citations.label: RideWithGPS: UCI Gravel Suisse - The Summit 2025
lecol.cc: Ribble Outliers Gravel Season Recap

key_takeaways: The UCI Gravel Suisse debuted in 2024 on the UCI calendar

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners
